newsitem.title: GERMANY: FDP leaders say party firmly opposed to tax hikes.
newsitem.headline: FDP leaders say party firmly opposed to tax hikes.

text.p: Several leaders from Germany's Free Democrats (FDP) said on Friday the party would remain firmly opposed to tax increases to fill holes in the government's budget.

Speaking ahead of the FDP's party congress in Wiesbaden this weekend, deputy FDP chairman Rainer Bruederle and former justice minister Sabine Leutheusser-Schnarrenberger said tax increases would be harmful for the economy.
"We will not yield on our concept of tax reduction, even if we run the danger of annoying our coalition partners," Bruederle said in an interview with ZDF television.
He said there could be no retreat on the government's earlier promise to lower the so-called "solidarity" income tax surcharge by two points to 5.5 percent in 1998.
"We will only be able to break the logjam on the necessary reforms with a reduction in the tax burden," Bruederle said in another interview with German radio.

The party, which provides Chancellor Helmut Kohl's centre-right alliance with its 12-seat parliamentary majority, has styled itself as the champion of lower taxes but now faces pressure to agree to a tax hike to fill a projected budget shortfall of 18 billion marks ($10.5 billion).

FDP leader Wolfgang Gerhardt has repeatedly opposed a rise in fuel tax or value-added tax -- two options Finance Minister Theo Waigel has not ruled out as he battles to meet the entry criteria for Europe's planned single currency.
"We have to do everything we can to consolidate the budget without always resorting to raising taxes," said Leutheusser-Schnarrenberger in an interview with NDR radio.
